p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 21st report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 18 January 2024, 7 February 2024 and 14 February 2024.
The committee resolved to present the following 65 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

span.span: 2. The following 7 ministerial responses to petitions were received.
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 14

p.span: From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding Overseas Visitors Health Cover (EN4202)
From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition regarding ticket reselling company Viagogo (EN4350)

From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition requesting that the ACCC be added to the terms of reference of the 'Inquiry into ASIC's capacity and capability to respond to reports of alleged misconduct' (EN5423)
From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition requesting that legislation be introduced requiring all imported retail goods to be labelled with their Co2 equivalent emissions (EN5428)
From the Minister for Finance to a petition regarding privacy concerns around the Australian Government's Digital ID program (EN5485)
From the Minister for Defence to a petition requesting that Australia's Force Posture Agreement with the United States be terminated (EN5543)
From the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme to a petition regarding doctors being responsible for NDIS medical forms (EN5550)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 65 petitions:
Road Safety

The changes to the current standards will mean that autistic people wil face discrimination and even more stigma due to incorrect beliefs. There is no evidence autistic drivers are any less safe than allistic driver. There is already a driving test that dictates if someone is eligble to drive.
We therefore ask the House to reverse the national standards that govern driving fitness agaisnt autistic people
from 51 citizens (Petition No. EN5709)
Nuclear Energy

The U.S. will lay out the first international strategy to commercialize nuclear fusion power at the upcoming UN climate summit in Dubai, U.S. Special Envoy on Climate Change John Kerry will say on Monday, two sources familiar with the announcement said.

Fusion could have an important advantage over today's nuclear fission plants that split atoms, as it does not produce long-lasting radioactive waste. If deployed successfully, it could also provide a cheap source of carbon-free electricity.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. Instigate a committee of International nuclear lawyers to review laws. Join the US, UK, EU in acknowledging fusion and developing it in Australia Outside the fission regulations.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5712)
Prime Minister
Loss of Confidence in Parliament
No-Confidence Vote
Criminal Activity or Misconduct
Constitutional Violations
Health Issues or Incapacity
Election Loss

We therefore ask the House to use their power to remove Anthony Albanese due to a lack of confidence in his ability to govern Australia, especially considering his handling of The Voice referendum and the wasted tax dollars."
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5714)
Trade Unions
UNIONS ARE BUSINESESS THEY ARE NOT A CHARITY WHICH GIVE AID TO ITS MEMEBERS
UNIONS IN FACT ARE PART OF LABOR PARTY WHICH INFLUENCES POLICIES TO AID UNIONS INTEREST NOT THE PEOPLE OF AUSTRALIA
NOT PAYING TAX IS FRAUD AGAINST ALL AUSTRALIN TAX PAYERS
We therefore ask the House to DEMAND UNIONS PAY THEIR TAX
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5717)
Medicare
ONLY AGED PENSIONERS & AUSTRALIN FULL TIME STUDENTS TO 25 NOT TO PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY
ALL AUSTRALIANS MUST BE MANDATED TO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THEIR MEDICAL COSTS & NOT BE SUBSIDIZED BY THE WORKING AUSTRALIANS
WE HAVE A CRISIS IN HEALTH/HOSPITALS, WE DEMAND

ALL ON WELFARE OF NDIS, JOKEEPER, PRISONERS, LOW INCOME NO MORE TAX FREE THREASHOLD TO PAY THEIR MEDICARE LEVY WHY SHOULD THEY NOT PAY FOR THEIR OWN MEIDCAL CARE? TAX ATY=ERS MUST NOT BE SUBSIDIZING EITHER ALL THE ASSISNACES ON WELFARE
We therefore ask the House to DEMAND ALL AUSTRALIANS TO PAY THEIR MEDCARE LEVY (ONLY AGED PENSIONERS & FULL TIME AUSTRALIAN STUDENTS TO 25 TO BE EXEMPT)
ALL AUSTRALIANS MUST BE RESPOSIBLE FOR THEIR ONW MEDICAL COSTS
WE CANNOT AFFORD SUBSIDIZATION
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5718)
Nuclear Energy

The IAEA World Fusion Outlook 2023 report confirms that fusion energy reactors do not contain fissile fuel, contrary to Mr. Bowen's comparison of fusion with fission in petition EN4147. The people of Australia are interested in leading the world in clean, safe energy that produces employment and new industries and the development of a fusion energy industry gives Australia an opportunity to do so, it also offers the opportunity to have clean, safe energy combined with renewables, batteries and hydrogen not like fission which can only deploy to 39 countries. They have even acknowledged this at COP 29. They acknowledged fusion to not be covered by the non-proliferation treaty. Fusion is already internationally acknowledged to not be covered by the international laws of nuclear energy and Australia can be held liable in civil litigations involving fusion. ANSTO is out of touch with this technology and legislated to administer it as the laws were instituted for fission and fusion is being separated from those laws to help develop it faster. Australia needs to involve itself in this international aim now.

We therefore ask the House to change the prohibition on the approval of nuclear (fission) power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 to differentiate between fission and fusion nuclear technologies. The Australian government has no need to change its plans to the longstanding moratorium on nuclear fission power and weapons in Australia, or the laws which prohibit its deployment.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5719)
Nuclear Energy

Regarding petition EN5335 on the development of nuclear fusion reactors, the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen replied. He mistakenly assumed incorrectly that the petition talked about reactors. The petition, EN5335, discussed the need for an Australian legislative wording change to support the international industry development of the nuclear fusion industry and bring it out of the shadow and the infamous past of Nuclear fission and thereby provide an avenue for Australia to further lead in the international renewable, battery, and hydrogen clean green energy development. There's an untapped opportunity to stimulate Australian industries, increase export value, and foster innovation and education. It will provide Australia with an opportunity to be a leader in SE Asia and the world.

We therefore ask the House to alter the legislative wording on the prohibition on the approval of nuclear power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and to differentiate between nuclear technologies. (Fission and Fusion) and do not alter The government's plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power (Fission) in Australia or the laws which prohibit fission deployment. We also ask that Fusion be treated similarly to the US, and UK and be taken out of ANSTO administration and administered by the environmental agency to allow its faster development in line with international laws.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN5720)
Parliamentary Standards

The behavior of politicians in question time is disgraceful. When a serious question is asked there is shouting out and worse still name calling, mocking and evasive or questions not answered. Every time a politician gets up and mocks a serious question, they are mocking the Australian public. It is further evidence how out of touch, arrogant and uncaring our politicians are.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a Code of Conduct for politicians. We the taxpayer expect questions answered, the person asking the question to be answered and the mocking name calling and childlike behavior to stop. This behavior is unacceptable and done as a deflection because they don't know the answer of think its clever to degrade the person asking the question. This behavior would not be tolerated in any other workplace and should not be tolerated by us the taxpayer.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5722)
Renewable Energy

WE HAVE A CRISIS IN ENERGY & HERE IS OUR GOVERNEMENTS SUBSIDIZING THE MANY ENRGIES THAT PRETEND TO BE RENWEABLES BUT IN FACT ARE MORE POLLUTING OR DOING MORE ENVIRONEMENTAL DAMAGED TO OUR ENVIRONMENT!
ELECTRIC CARS MUST PAY HIGHER TAX IN LINE WITH THE MANY AUSTRALIANS WHO PAY THE PETROL TAX OUR GOVERNEMENT TELL US TO USE FOR OUR ROADS
ELECTRIC CARS ARE HEAVIER & DO MORE DAMAGE TO OUR ROADS
ALL RENEWALBES ARE NON RECYBLE & ARE DISPOSSED IN LANDFILL POLLUTING OUR ANY UNDERGROUND WATER & SOILS!
WIND TURBINES & TOXIC SOLAR PANESL . BATTERIES ALL ARE IMPORTED MADE BY USING FOSSIL FUELE AS CHINE & SLAVED LABOR!
IT IS NOW DESTROYING OUR FARMS, FORESTS & OCEANS
KILLING ANIMAL HABITATS

We therefore ask the House to OUR GOVERNEMENTS TO STOP SUBSIDIZNG THE RENWEABLE ENERGIEGS & ELECTRIC CARS & MUST MANDATE ELECTRIC CARS TO PAY A HIGHER TAX FOR USING OUR ROADS AS WE PETROL CAR USERS THAT OUR POLATICNS TELL US THE PETROL EXCISE IS UDED FOR OUR ROADS
ELECTRIC CARS MUST BE BANNED USING OUR ROADS
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5727)
Telecommunications
My home landline and internet connection, was disconnected on 15 January, 2021, due to the NBN roll out. I was with Telstra at the time, and had a non-wireless compatible connection.
Due to my sensitivity to wireless and wireless compatible devices, I am unable to connect to the NBN HFC, which is available for my home address.
I do not have a mobile, as like other wireless devices, it gives me a headache.
Since my ADSL disconnection, I use public telephones to make calls within Australia, and I use library computers (which are hardwired) for internet access.
I recently became aware that the ADSL is still operating, for IINET customers, although new ADSL connections are no longer offered.
We therefore ask the House to arrange for new ADSL connections to be made available, with the option for a non-wireless compatible connection.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5729)
Banking and Financial Services

Towns and suburbs are losing bank branches and bank-owned ATMs. Some retailers are refusing to accept cash to pay for goods and services. Most Australians believe that banknotes issued by the RBA are legal tender and must be accepted by merchants.
Australia's cash system is in crisis because of rising costs and lack of support from banks.
We are increasingly vulnerable to outages, privacy breaches, hackers and rising transaction fees.
Some people need cash everyday and all Australians need cash sometimes. We need to be able to access cash locally and use cash to buy food and essential groceries.
We therefore ask the House to enshrine our right to choose physical legal tender notes and coins to pay for food and essential groceries.
from 45 citizens (Petition No. EN5730)
Nuclear Energy

The minister has failed to address the request in Petition EN5335 to consider developing Nuclear Fusion power plants and the associated industry. We did not request it be developed to solve net zero by 2030, We are proposing a new technological industry to advance Australia in exports, technology, education and future employment of Australians.

We therefore ask the House to ratify and update the current antiquated nuclear laws to allow a fusion industry to be developed in Australia outside the fission restrictions as fusion does not pose the same risks as fission. We recognise the government's push for renewables. The fusion industry needs renewables to succeed and the renewables need fusion to become viable and Australia has an international place to help with this. As well as help SE Asia develop fusion energy and industry to avoid fission reactors being placed near Australia and posing a sovereign risk. We need the nuclear laws modified to identify fusion as they do not at present and then to separate it to be managed outside the nuclear regulator as is being done in the US, UK and the EU as a fusion reactor does not have fissile material in cannot be identified as a nuclear reactor and that is a civil liability issue if a fusion accident occurs at present and identified by the IAEA.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5731)
Public Broadcasting
ABS, SBS & NITV MUST BE STOPPED NOW FROM BEING OUTRAGEOUSLY SUBSIDIZED BY TAX PAYERS WHEN THEY REFUSE TO FOLLOW THEIR CHARTER & ARE SO OBVIOUSLY BIASED TOWARDS LEFT WING IDEOLGY

IT ESENTIAL IN A DEMICRACY A TAX PAYERS SUBSIDIZED BERURACRCY MEDIA MUST FOLLOW THEIR CHARTER & PROVIDE PROGRAMS FOR ALL PEOPLE OF AUSTRALIA THE GOVERNEMENT NOW CUT THE AUST. POST SERVICES BUT REFUSES TO CUT THE OVER SUBSIDIZED,OVEFRPAID BEURACRATES
THEABC, SBS & NITV PLAY POLITIC
We therefore ask the House to STOP ALLFUNDING TO THE ABC SBS & NITV
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5741)
Public Sector Governance
The Australian Government CANNOT account for the spending of Taxpayers Money.

We therefore ask the House to pass legislation that allows the transparency of ALL spending, in each seperate Government Department, for each and every area, that the said department, spends Australian Taxpayers Money!!
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5743)
Waste Management and Recycling

It is unconscionable in this juncture of our environmental timeline to allow manufacturers to continue creating unsustainable garbage by packaging products in non recyclable and non biodegradable packaging.

It is completely redundant for Australians to be conscientiously trying to compost, reuse and recycle things for the benefit of the environment and their fellow beings future when manufacturers simply create more harmful packaging by the truckload ad infinitum!
We therefore ask the House to tionable steps and processes to make this a TOP PRIORITY.
We, the undersigned are increasingly concerned about the amount of unsustainable packaging we are forced to throw in the garbage, and therefore landfill
As far as the law permits, these are our requests for action...
No manufacturer be permitted to supply products in packaging that is not recyclable or preferably biodegradable.
We suggest that they have an 24 month window to phase out the old packaging
(similar to the cutoff timeframe for plastic bags in our local supermarkets)
We also propose an incentive be offered to businesses that commit to completing this within a 12 month timeframe
If amendments to the above proposal need to be implemented, we request that this be done with full transparency and consultation with the public and the Minister for Environment
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5746)

subdebateinfo.title: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America

p.span: International Relations: Australia and the United States of America
The current terms of the alliance with the United States have long been outdated. They were set when there was a cold war.
While we've been a staunch supporter of them. They go to war. We go to war.
That's not the case if we get attacked. We go to war... they'll think about it.
This doesn't help us in geopolitical negotiations, it doesn't help our reputation globally as those who have legitimate grudges with the US see us in the same sense.
It's time to renegotiate the terms of the of treaty. Either they sign to come to our aid no matter what, or we can pick and choose the wars we enter.
The United States has a hand in every single war there is. This stretches our own forces thin if we go to them all.
As their friend if they're attacked at home, we should be there. But the other wars are optional.
We therefore ask the House to push for a new treaty with the United States of America for a more even deal.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN5748)
Personal Information and Privacy
The proposed Digital ID Bill 2023 is a direct threat to Australians' freedom.
In light of all the digital data breaches recently, the Australian people require their government to protect from ID theft no facilitate it.
A digital ID, when used in conjunction with a central bank digital currency, is the perfect platform for the government to track Australians' every move.

It is being advertised as voluntary however, Section 74(4) of the Digital ID Bill allows the Digital ID to be made compulsory if a bureaucrat is "satisfied it is appropriate to do so". This statement therefore in misleading as it means this legislation can be made mandatory quickly and without public consultation.
A Digital ID has the potential for unprecedented, unwarranted and unwanted government control and overreach.
We therefore ask the House to discard this proposed legislation or amend it to ensure it will never be compulsory and no Australian will ever be disadvantaged by not having a Digital ID.
from 99 citizens (Petition No. EN5749)
Migration

The Amman Office takes too long to process a partner visa. Offices in other countries like Indonesia, Japan, Fiji, USA, and European countries process a visa in as little as 5 weeks. This is not special about 1-2 case(s) only. We have seen various partner visas processed in 5-10 weeks. However, the Amman Office takes 1 to 2 years for processing (particularly talking for applicants from Pakistan). There are some case that have even surpassed the period of 2 years. All the applicants, as a requirement of visa, are sponsored by the Australian citizens and Permanent Residents as a guarantee.

On the contrary, the onshore partner visa (Subclass 820) are processed quite quickly (around 3-6 months). This is just not understandable at all. Partners living offshore have to bear a lot of stress, anxiety, depression and the pain of separation. This seriously afffects our relationship and household.

We therefore ask the House to please consider our request and see what is the root cause behind Amman office processing visas very slow. If they have a backlog, the solution should be expediting the process or employ more people, but not keeping families a part.
It is our sincere, genuine, polite, and earnest reuquest to kindly help us in this trying time.
Appreciating and thanking every single member involved in resolving this genuine issue.
from 105 citizens (Petition No. EN5750)
Personal Information and Privacy
We the people of Australia, would like to reject the proposed Digital ID 2023, due to the potential for misuse in the future.
This type of technology has the potential to be linked to all government systems, financial systems (and purchases), as well as online systems and activity.

The government needs to heed the example of the Chinese communist system, whereby social credits are linked to their Digital ID, limiting the basic rights of those who are accused of dissent. It is basically a digital gaol.
This technology also has the potential to be linked with carbon credits and be used to control what people do and buy.
I'm sure that the government has good intent for implementing this type of system, however the potential dangers outweigh any perceived benefit
We therefore ask the House to reject the proposed Digital ID Bill 2023
from 99 citizens (Petition No. EN5751)
Middle East
Support Israel
We therefore ask the House to condemn Hamas and its supporters including Iran, Qatar and those who march in Australia chanting 'from the river to the sea'.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5754)
Middle East
I publicly condemn the killing of children in Gaza by Israel.
We therefore ask the House to do the same.
from 86 citizens (Petition No. EN5756)
Banking and Financial Services
Vendor finance should be offered to sellers of homes farms businesses it's not

We therefore ask the House to examine the vendor finance options .currently real estate agents won't offer it or mention it . Some home owners farmers and businesses want sell but in this climate and the way finance is banks won't lend but some home owners farmers and businesses are able to carry a purchase. Why can't real-estate agents offer this option to the seller. ( because agents make no money from it ) that's why it's never offered
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5765)
Working Holiday Maker Program

Please recognize the challenges faced by the Victorian High Country in attracting and retaining workers, particularly in the housekeeping and hospitality sectors. The current shortage of workers in this region is having a detrimental impact on local businesses and communities, and we believe that including jobs in the Victorian High Country for the 88 days of the Working Holiday Visa requirement will address this issue and benefit both the local economy and the working holiday visa holders. This shortage of workers has led to operational challenges for local businesses like all the Victorian Ski resorts and is hindering the sustainable growth of the tourism industry in the area.

We therefore ask the House to consider including jobs in the Victorian High Country under the 88 days requirement for the Working Holiday Visa program specially housekeeping and hospitality. At the moment this line of work is only counted if work is done in northern or remote and very remote Australia, we believe places like Buller is remote enough. This inclusion will not only provide a solution to the labor shortage in the region but also offer working holiday visa holders a unique and enriching experience in a diverse and picturesque setting of the Victorian High Country. We believe that by addressing the labor shortage in the Victorian High Country, we can create a win-win situation for both local businesses and working holiday visa holders. We kindly request your support in considering this
from 306 citizens (Petition No. EN5767)
International Students

On 11 December 2023, the Department of Home Affairs published Migration Strategy, with many proposals to fix Australian migration system. Amongst those proposed changes is the change of Age Limit for Temporary Graduate Visa (Visa 485) applicants. This Age limit is currently set at 50 years old, and is proposed to be lower to just 35 years old. This particular proposal, if implemented, will severely reduce the ability to attract high-value international students to Australia, especially those coming to do Post-Graduate and Research Courses (Masters and PhD students). Because this cohort of international student usually have built experience and knowledge throughout many years after finishing their Bachelor degrees, thus they are usually older compared to students in Bachelor courses. Moreover, the Migration Strategy does not indicate whether the age change will be applied to current students, or students who have enrolled but have not begun their study in Australia yet. If the changes are implemented regardless of current status of students' studying, it will seriously damage the image and reputation of Australia, and its trustworthiness and honesty.

We therefore ask the House to question the Department of Home Affairs and the Australian Government in regards to the changes to Temporary Graduate Visa (Visa 485), with careful considerations, analyses, and researches on the consequences and impacts to current and future international students. At the very least, there should be a transition period, and the changes should only be applied to future students who enrol after specific date.
from 4,988 citizens (Petition No. EN5768)
Animal Welfare

We, the undersigned, draw to the attention of the House the potential danger of tea tree oil to small animals, especially cats and dogs. Tea tree oil contains various types of chemicals called terpenes, Terpenes are rapidly absorbed into the body whether taken orally or on the skin. As little as 7 drops of 100% oil has resulted in severe poisoning.
We request that the House take action to raise awareness about the potential dangers of tea tree oil to small animals.

The reason I am writing this petition is because I recently rescued 2 stray kittens, not knowing much about cats and being told that tea tree oil is a suitable flee treatment, I soaked them in a water-soluble solution and washed it off. shortly after one of them was unresponsive and I immediately rushed them both to the emergency vet. Long story short, one of the cats was so severely poisoned that it had to be put down, the other one is making a recovery. This was not even 100% pure oil only 20%
Your petitioners therefore request that the House take action to address this issue.
We therefore ask the House to
Require that all tea tree oil products sold in Australia carry warning labels indicating that they are not to be used on cats, dogs or any other household pets or small animals.
Raise awareness about what household products, such as tee tree oil are harmful and toxic to pets and small animals.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5769)
Nuclear Energy
We are asking for FUSION.
We are not asking for FISSION.
NOT THE SAME THING.
The UK and U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) recommend regulating FUSION under a by-product materials framework, rather than using the existing nuclear regime.
Again, this makes a clear distinction between FISSION and FUSION, recognising that the current regulatory regime unhelpfully uses the word "nuclear" as shorthand for nuclear FISSION.
We are asking that the ban stays in place for FISSION and that the laws be adjusted to allow a FUSION Industry plus FUSION-only power stations using FUSION to be developed.

This is a new industry, with big prospects, and Australia should be involved as an early adopter. It offers employment, investment, export, manufacturing, new technology, power generation, maritime propulsion, space travel and environmental savings.
This is not NUCLEAR FISSION it is about FUSION.

We therefore ask the House to amend any legislation prohibiting the use of FUSION energy and RETAIN THE PROHIBITION on NUCLEAR FISSION energy or any combined, co-located, joined Fission and Fusion power plant.

We request that the government set up and Instigate a committee for fusion energy research and development with international industry advisers, Scientists, physicists, Engineers, management, financial advisers and fusion lawyers to review laws and commercialism outside ANSTO and ARPANSA to provide independent verifications of safety management.
We also ask the government/parliament to allow the building of a research FUSION power plant in Australia and to allow commercial FUSION power plants to be built with public and private investment.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5770)
Middle East
For many decades Australian citizens have served in the Israel Defense Forces (IDF).
In light of both current events in Israel and the Gaza Strip and the roles and actions of the IDF over many decades, it is unacceptable that Australian citizens should continue to serve in the IDF.
It is now clear that the IDF is actively engaged in roles and actions that are completely inconsistent with Australian citizenship, including:
• ethnic cleansing
• collective punishment
• the maintenance of an apartheid state
• the use of live fire against unarmed civilians
• the illegal occupation and annexation of Palestinian territory
• the destruction of civilian infrastructure and residential property
We therefore ask the House to enact legislation that will prevent Australian citizens from serving in the Israel Defense Forces (IDF).
from 777 citizens (Petition No. EN5771)
Waste Management and Recycling

Single use plastics are killing our earth, and there are so many ways we can crack down on big corporations to stop/reduce single use plastic production. Every year, 12 million tonnes of plastic are dumped into our oceans, which kill ocean life. Large companies like Coca-Cola, and Pepsi-co plan on increasing their plastic production by 3x

We therefore ask the House to limit big companies manufacturing and importing single use plastics, to instead ask corporate giants to use glass bottles, cardboard and paper packets, glass cases for makeup, just anything to reduce plastic use in Australia.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5772)
Veterans

The Department of Immigration and Border Protection enforce a 22 page code of conduct for registered Migration Agents which provides procedural protection and safeguards for migrants in their dealings with these Agents…

By comparison the DVA endorsed Code of Ethics to the guide the principles, values and behaviours expected of advocates trained under the Advocacy Training and Development Program is little more than 1 page, and is drafted with a view to how Advocates deal with the DVA. Little consideration has been given to safeguarding Veterans in their dealings with Advocates…
The lack of procedural protection and safeguards the DVA endorsed Code exhibits when compared to the Migration Agents code is concerning…

As a result of their service many Australian Defence Force Veterans suffer significant and debilitating mental and physical conditions, and are among the most vulnerable members of Australian society. It is more than appropriate for these Veterans to be given the highest level of protection in their interactions with both paid and volunteer advocates, and as such it seems reasonable to develop and legislate an advocates code of conduct which will at least equal, if not exceed the protective measures the Migration Agents Code provides migrants.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause to come into being a comprehensive and detailed Veterans Advocate code of conduct which provides protective measures which at least equals the Migration Agents Code provides migrants.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN5773)
International Students

The Migration Strategy unveiled on 11/12/2023, outlines a proposal to amend the age limit for the Temporary Graduate Visa subclass 485 (TGV) from 50 to 35 commencing in mid-2024. Recognising the pivotal role of international education as a top export sector for Australia, it is imperative to acknowledge that genuine international students meticulously plan their academic pursuits in Australia for years in advance. The TGV has been historically encouraged by predecessor governments as an enticing incentive, offering invaluable Australian work experience to promote international education. Consequently, international students across various academic levels, including doctoral candidates, anticipate the TGV as an integral facet of their Australian educational journey.

While we commend the Government's commitment to enhancing the migration system, the proposed reduction in the age limit for TGV in mid-2024 raises concerns about its impact on current international students. A substantial cohort of existing international students and commencing students in 2024 will reach the age of 35 upon completing their courses post-mid-2024, thus being adversely affected. This segment of students, having made critical decisions to study in Australia under the assurance of eligibility for the TGV within the existing age limit, will face an inequitable, invidious situation should the proposed changes be implemented. Such circumstances run contrary to the principles of having a fair go, being a core Australian value.

We therefore ask the House to consider the implementation of a grandfather policy, thereby affording current and soon-to-be international students the opportunity to apply for the TGV under the current criteria.
from 808 citizens (Petition No. EN5774)
Israel
Israel are under threat by hundreds of millions people on its borders who wish for 'from the river to the see, we will be free'. Israel need's unconditional international support now.
We therefore ask the House to give their immediate full support for Israel
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5776)
Skilled Migration Program

The 191 visa is a pathway of 491 skilled visa, where the people living and working on 491 are paying taxes same as PR holders in fact they are staying in regional areas and contributing to the regional economy where most of the PR holder do not go. Therefore, the role of 491 visa holders is critical but their rights are compromised as in everything they are treated as foreigners. They can't buy properties, cant get government sponsored courses and many other privilege's. As the visa holders are intending to live permanently but this barrier is hindering that aim.

We therefore ask the House to kindly consider reducing the 191 eligibility requirements from 3 years to 2 years in order to support the regional visa holders. This will add trust and security of the regional visa holders and allow them to invest in the country to secure the future of them and their families.
from 36 citizens (Petition No. EN5777)
Work-Life Balance

As Australia enters a period where knowledge work dominates; it's clear that quality, not quantity. Creativity, not man hours; that will drive our future growth. We are a nation exhausted from COVID, in a loneliness crisis with depression and anxiety on the rise. We have no creativity and quality to spare and require a society and work/life balance that brings out our best.
This petition is for the good of the human spirit. It is the labour leisure trade off we were all assured would come. It is how we will rebuild as a nation and be a nation worth rebuilding.
Real incomes have gone nowhere, housing is unaffordable, don't deny us this. It is our light at the end of a long dark journey.
We therefore ask the House to instate a four day work week.
from 38 citizens (Petition No. EN5778)
Regional Security

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) consistently uses the threat of a violent takeover of Taiwan to persuade elections and create fear within the Taiwan Strait. Unlike the United States, who, despite their commitment to a One China policy, have shared their intention to defend Taiwan against an attack by the People's Republic of China (PRC), the Australian Government's response has only been to advocate for a peaceful solution; however, in the situation that a peaceful solution cannot be found, Taiwan would rely on Australia for support.

Australia, due to its geography and influence, is the best defence for the people of Taiwan in the event of an immoral and violent invasion. A conflict between the PRC and Taiwan would be internationally devastating, but to allow an authoritarian government to use threats of war and violence as a way to control Taiwan is a failure of democratic values shared by both Australia and Taiwan.

It has been over 50 years since Australia established ties with the PRC, and Taiwan has been independently governed over this entire period. Whether we acknowledge Taiwan's sovereignty or not, we can acknowledge the importance of its independence for the overall benefit of global trade and human rights within the Asia-Pacific and condemn threats of violence made by the CCP.

We therefore ask the House to pledge Australia's intention to defend Taiwan from a violent invasion and to condemn the actions and words of the Chinese Communist Party that threaten or suggest a violent takeover of Taiwan.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN5779)
Australian Passport Office
All Australians deserve affordable travel, think of the young and not rich.
We urge Parliament to:
* **Reject the proposed $395 passport fee.**
* **Review fees to ensure affordability for all.**
* **Find alternative funding models.**

At $325, the Australian passport is already the world's most expensive, exceeding Canada, New Zealand, Japan, and even the UK. This hike would unfairly burden families, young people, and lower-income Australians.
An Australian passport is a symbol of national identity, not a luxury. It should not limit travel opportunities.
**Sign and share this petition to demand affordable passports for all!**
We therefore ask the House to immediately stop any further increases to the cost of Australian passports.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5780)
Universities

Having to pay upwards of $300,0000 for a medical education is ridiculous—however this is the reality for many who are offered Australian Full-Fee places in such courses, rather than the much cheaper CSPs. Australia has a shortage of doctors—especially in rural areas. To make people such high fees—leaving them weighed by debt—is absolutely ridiculous and actively deters people from choosing to become doctors.
We therefore ask the House to allocate more money towards creating more CSPs, which will ensure more people are able to access CSPs in medical courses in universities across Australia.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5781)
Middle East

The United Nations and its various bodies, and international human rights organisations, have all stated that the ongoing siege of Gaza and Israel's actions in Gaza since October 7 2023, represent clear violations of international law, which could amount to war crimes; crimes against humanity; and genocide. These crimes are codified in Division 268 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code, meaning Australia has the jurisdiction to investigate and prosecute persons involved in their commission, regardless of their nationality or on the territory where the crime took place.

An undisclosed number of dual citizens of Australia and Israel were part of the over 360,000 reservists summoned by the Israel Defense Force (IDF) following the October 7 Hamas attack to "join the fight".
These reservists were subsequently flown, some individually and some via repatriation flights, to Israel to join the IDF's attack on Gaza and throughout the Occupied Palestinian Territory.
Given the catastrophic situation and the unfolding genocide in Gaza,

We therefore ask the House to establish an urgent parliamentary inquiry to inquire into the involvement of Australian nationals in the IDF's operations in the OPT and an Australian Federal Police investigation of those individuals involved in the IDF's offensive.
For the safety of Australia, we must ensure that we are committed to upholding our laws so that citizens alleged to be involved in the commission of grave crimes are investigated and prosecuted.
Such an inquiry should request that Israel cooperate fully with the inquiry and any investigation.
from 967 citizens (Petition No. EN5783)
Banking and Financial Services

The Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) Supervisory Cost Recovery Levy (Levy) is the government's means of recovering ASIC's regulatory costs from the industry sectors it regulates. In June 2023, Minister for Financial Services Stephen Jones announced that temporary levy relief for personal financial advice licensees that was in place for 2020-21 and 2021-22 would not be extended. Subsequently, ASIC has stated that the costs it needs to recover for the year are $47M for each adviser. However, while fees for advisers are expected to increase by more than double, fees for Australian Financial Services Licensees (AFSLs) are set to remain at $1500. We are concerned by the significant cost asymmetry that has emerged between individual financial advisers and AFSL holders. It is AFSL holders who are responsible for the conduct of the advisers that operate under their licenses and who must ensure that the financial services their advisers are authorised to provide are delivered honestly, fairly and in accordance with law. We submit that ASIC's main regulatory focus (and therefore its costs) relate to AFSLs, rather than individual advisers.

We therefore ask the House to request Minister Stephen Jones to by regulation increase the minimum amount payable by an AFSL from its current fixed amount of $1,500 before invoices for the levy are issued in early 2024 to ensure equitable outcomes for the financial advice sector.
from 461 citizens (Petition No. EN5784)
Domestic and Family Violence

All victims of family and domestic violence are expected to endure re living any events in a court face to face for an order to be made for protection regardless of the victims mental health to have to go through with this.

Evidence should be allowed to be submitted with out the victim being put through this. In my situation the offender laughs at this and continues the abuse if the victim feels weak to show up I come out in a rash all over didn't sleep thinking about having to re live this and see that person. The matter got struck out even though I had explained and provided evidence I can't be there it's made me very ill.

While I've had blocked messages from the abuser laughing I can't do anything about it. We need more protection a better way to put a stop to it that doesn't involve the victim going through more harm to the point we actually give up on fighting for our safety.
The police have no power unless it goes though a court first this is also not acceptable we need to feel safe all the time not once a court order is in place.
We therefore ask the House to implement better policies around family violence a court should accept any proof of family violence with out the victim needing to be present in a court room.
Under no circumstances a family violence order to be struck out but only to be adjoined with interim
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5785)
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Currently, CBD oil costs approximately $250 for a 50mL. It is extremely expensive, yet a life changing medication for many people. We need to make it more affordable and accessible for Australians.
We therefore ask the House to put TGA approved CBD products on the PBS for chronic pain and PTSD.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN5789)
International Students

We, the undersigned, submit this petition expressing shared concern regarding the recent announcement by the Australia Home Affairs Minister and Immigration Minister imposing age restrictions on the SC485 Graduate Visa for international students. We believe that the proposed age limitation, specifically targeting individuals aged 35 and above, introduces a discriminatory barrier that undermines the principles of equal opportunity and inclusivity in Australia's educational landscape.

Australia has been celebrated for its commitment to providing quality education for students from diverse backgrounds and experiences. However, the introduction of age-based restrictions on the SC485 Graduate Visa challenges the notion of fairness and equality, particularly for mature-age international students who aspire to contribute their unique perspectives and skills to our society.

Mature-age students often bring a wealth of experience, a strong work ethic, and valuable insights that enhance the academic and cultural fabric of our institutions. By imposing age restrictions, we risk limiting the potential contributions of a significant segment of the international student community, contrary to the values that Australia has traditionally embraced.

We therefore ask the House to reconsider the discriminatory age restrictions on the SC485 Graduate Visa and to explore alternative measures that align with the principles of fairness, equality, and inclusivity. We believe that a person's age should not be a factor in determining their eligibility for a visa that significantly impacts their ability to pursue post-graduate opportunities in Australia. Please kindly review and reconsider the proposed age restrictions on the SC485 Graduate Visa.
from 586 citizens (Petition No. EN5790)
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Gaza

We are deeply concerned about the unfolding humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. Over 20,000 innocent civilians have been killed with the majority being women, children and babies. 1.7 million people have been internally displaced and there is no safe place of refuge. The Australian government has a proud recent history in supporting Ukrainians and Afghans fleeing conflict by providing humanitarian settlement support through the Humanitarian Settlement Program (HSP).

HSP is an established infrastructure able to provide vital support to new arrivals. The government historically issued Ukrainian and Afghan arrivals temporary humanitarian visas, which provided access to essential supports.

Palestinians arriving from Gaza on visitors visas cannot work, access Medicare, HSP, income support or schooling. They are completely reliant on their family, community, and charities to provide essential services.
We therefore ask the House to porary humanitarian visas immediately so they are given access to support
Expedite Palestinians protection visa claims given Palestinians have no right of return to their home country and the scale of devastation in Gaza.
Give Palestinian arrivals humanitarian settlement support (HSP)
Allow Palestinian children to enrol in school.

Provide easily accessible information to the Australian public on how the $25 million pledged by the Australian government to the Palestinian community in Australia has been distributed. Sponsors of Palestinian arrivals are desperately reaching out to services for support given their complex psychosocial, health, and mental health needs. This will alleviate the burden being placed on the Australian community and NGOs to provide new arrivals settlement support.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN5793)
Homelessness
Implementing Finland's model to resolve homelessness in Australia. Homelessness is everyone's problem. Urgent and faster action must be taken.

We therefore ask the House to implement Finland's model to spear head this serious and very grave situation. The housing market needs also to be partly regulated. Affordable housing needs to be built and funded by states and major cities. This project should be carried forward by any government at anyone-time. Patience and long term approach is needed to achieve great outcomes when it comes to mental health/addiction homelessness, offering temporary accommodation (one room and share kitchen) until permanent small accommodation complete with lease/contract can be offered. Mental health counselling, therapy and rehabilitation and assistance in finding suitable employment via the right channels such as 'At Work Australia' or similar. Safe single parents' accommodation with child care in situ to assist parents to keep their current employment or assist them to find one.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN5804)
Banking and Financial Services
No cashless Australia what if there's a war a emp or solar flair what if we want to sell our stuff or escaping domestic violence or what if there's we just want to be anonymous?
We therefore ask the House to publicly petition cashless society
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN5808)
Defence Recruitment

The presence of Coeliac Disease in an individual's application to the Australian Defence Force will award them a rejected application and a classification of 'Class 4—Medically Unfit for Service'. The ADF and wider spokespeople have justified this classification, as coeliac disease may prove difficult to cater for during various military activities and has the capacity to impede upon their physical capacity. These reasons are understandable, to an extent. Response to a related petition answered in May 2023 read, "Defence has retained members with coeliac disease who were diagnosed while in service, with appropriate employment and deployment restrictions.". The response then detailed that members with Coeliac Disease are treated on a case-by-case basis, and finally alluded to a possible review of Coeliac Disease treatment at recruitment.

Given that the ADF has and is currently catering to members who suffer from Coeliac Disease, it is clearly plausible for them to recruit new members with the disease. A role in reserve units may suit the flexibility Coeliac Disease requires. A complete adaption of all ADF roles for Coeliac Disease is not something which may be attainable. However, accommodating Coeliac Disease in reduced capacity roles, as the ADF is already doing with certain members, is a feasible step in the right direction.

We therefore ask the House to revisit the treatment of Coeliac Disease at recruitment. Rather than refusing all those with Coeliac Disease, instead treat recruits on a case-by-case basis for certain roles, as has already been done with prior-serving members.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN5816)
Nuclear Energy
With the recent achievement of fusion net energy gain in the United States, there is little doubt, in our view, that fusion will be the dominant source of energy by the end of the century.
The question now is: who will commercialise this incredible milestone first to reap the economic and national security benefits and gain the balance of global power as the world leader in energy?
We therefore ask the House to allow "Aneutronic fusion" and does not produce neutrons. It cannot be used to create bombs. It does not cause meltdowns. And it will not create waste.

If it is created by the fusing of hydrogen with boron-11, the fuel is a combination of the most abundant molecule on the planet (hydrogen) and an atom with sufficient supply to generate base-load fusion energy for the world for more than 1000 years. This is far longer than any other nuclear fission energy system or fossil fuel energy system.
Thanks to these benefits, the technology pathway to a functioning aneutronic fusion energy reactor is significantly less complicated, and therefore shorter and much less expensive.
We also request that you adopt similar legislation of fusion as the US and UK with the extra caveat to continue the ban on Fission.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5822)
Nuclear Energy

We have requested on several occasions and will continue until we get a clear answer on our request for a law change or to have licences issued for a new industry as this industry is being mistakenly entwined by antiquated legislation meant for another industry and by the older industries name this new industry is being tainted and falsely associated with the horrors, dangers, and problems of the older industry. These horrors, dangers, and problems do not exist in this new, similarly named industry.

We therefore ask the House to consider changing the laws as have the UK and the US on fusion energy research, its development, the building of power plants and the creation of an industry that Australia should be leading in as Australia first discovered Fusion.
With the appropriate regulation, investment and research facilities in Australia today, we anticipate that commercialising fusion energy could begin this decade.
We request this to maintain our country's secure sovereignty and leadership in safe, clean energy security and energy that can be used by all.
We also request that the laws for fission remain in place to keep Australians safe as they are. are at present.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5823)
Banking and Financial Services
Under the Australian Consumer Law, receipts must be issued as soon as possible for all purchases of $75 or more (excluding GST) regardless of whether payment was made by cash or card.
It is requested Customer Service in Australia gives the customer a receipt and bags if customer doesn't have own bags.
We therefore ask the House to reinstate legislation to ensure customers get receipts. For simplicity and to treat all customers as prospective business owners for all amounts purchases.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5826)
Universities

The current practice of withholding citizens' regular HECS loan contributions until the end of the financial year, coupled with the subsequent application of yearly indexation, places an undue financial burden on Australians pursuing higher education.
We therefore ask the House to review the repayments of HECS loans.
The proposed action plan is as follows:

1. Real-Time Application of Repayments: Institute a system that reflects citizens' HECS loan payments in real-time, aligning with the regular pay cycles. This will ensure that contributions are applied promptly and transparently, preventing unnecessary delays in reducing student loan balances.

2. Eliminate yearly indexation delay: Cease the practice of applying yearly indexation before government contributions are made to HECS loans. Instead, calculate indexation based on the actual outstanding balance at the time of payment, providing a fair and accurate representation of the loan's real value.

3. Transparency and Communication: improve communication channels to educate HECS loan holders about the repayment process, indexation calculations, and the impact of delayed government contributions. This will empower students to make informed financial decisions and alleviate the stress associated with unpredictable loan balances.

4. Regular review and adjustment: Establish a mechanism for periodic reviews of the HECS loan repayment system to ensure its continued effectiveness and responsiveness to the financial needs of students. Adjustments should be made based on economic conditions and the cost of living.
By implementing these changes, the government can demonstrate its commitment to supporting the educational pursuits of young Australians while alleviating financial stress associated with HECS loans.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN5829)
Public Broadcasting

We need to defund the ABC as it is constantly promoting left wing biassed agendas. This has once again been shown during the coverage on New Years eve with calls against Israel, calling our national day Invasion day.
Throughout the year the ABC has promoted only one side of the Voice campaign, continuously promoted gender politics as well as bullying anyone of the opposite oppinion to the presenters.
Then there is the Incident of ABC employees also promoting left wing wokeism agendas on social media all while being paid and funded by the taxpayers of which the majority do not agree with.
We therefore ask the House to defund the ABC to which they either be sold or dismantled.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN5830)
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Gaza

We, the undersigned, express deep concern over the alleged deceptive and misleading conduct by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) regarding the provision of consular support. Numerous Australian citizens and permanent residents have been reportedly misled into applying for visas for family members under the impression that this would facilitate consular support, particularly for crossing the Rafah border in crisis situations. This misunderstanding, stemming from DFAT's miscommunication, has led to significant financial and emotional distress.

We therefore ask the House to support a thorough investigation into DFAT's conduct in this matter. We request the Minister for Foreign Affairs direct an inquiry into DFAT officials regarding the clarity and consistency of their advice on consular support to Australian citizen and residents who have family members in Gaza. This investigation should aim to establish the truth, hold accountable those responsible for any misleading conduct, and implement corrective actions and measures to safeguarding the interests and well-being of Australian citizens and residents.
from 250 citizens (Petition No. EN5832)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

The outcome of the referendum aiming to acknowledge Indigenous Australians in our constitution through the establishment of a Voice does not accurately reflect our national identity. Regrettably, the discussion spiraled out of control, causing the genuine purpose behind Voice, Truth, and Treaty to be obscured by the surrounding noise. Despite this, each Australian cast their vote based on the belief that they were acting in the best interest of Indigenous Australians from their individual perspective. Nonetheless, the end result is deemed a mistake, and Australia is a noble nation that takes responsibility for its mistakes.

We therefore ask the House to discuss repeating the referendum to recognise Indigenous Australians in our constitution in the form of a Voice to parliament alongside the 2025 Federal Election so as to minimise the expense to the taxpayer, assuming there is sufficient time between whenever this petition is heard and the 2025 election date.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5833)
World Health Organization

WHO/ UN has already failed the world & does not deserve to be trusted. Their agendas are not in the public interest, are undemocratic, nefarious & aim to undermine the rights, responsibilities & respect afforded to our govt representatives, medical professionals, generally & individuals to choose for themselves & their dependants.
We therefore ask the House to
Either Withdraw Completely Financial Support, Membership & Authority from WHO.
OR
Open Referendum for Citizens to Decide, & Provide Unbiased, Non-Partisan Outlining of Proposed Amendments, with Realistic Outcomes of Each Choice Made
&/ OR
Provide Unbiased, Non-Partisan Outlining of Proposed Amendments, with Realistic Outcomes of Each Choice Made.
OR
Reject Any Binding Elements & Revert Back to Provisions Being Non-Binding, Optional & Suggestions, Backed By Real World Scientific Evidence.
OR
Reject Amendments Altogether

Change Their Liability's, in Which They Are To Be Held To Account For Their Actions, Decisions & Referrals (Unlike The Blind Agreement With Pharmaceutical Companies, Who Are For Profit & Control, Not Health)
from 56 citizens (Petition No. EN5836)
Migration: Business Innovation

We, concerned citizens, business professionals, and Australian residents, unite in urging the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship to address severe processing delays for Subclass 188 visa applicants in the Business Innovation and Investment stream. Many applicants, hopeful to contribute to Australia's economy, submitted their visas in 2020 with an expected 6-8 month processing time. Sadly, they have faced over three years of distressing delays, disrupting their lives and business plans, both professionally and personally.
We are also deeply concerned about the applicants' children included in these applications, who now exceed the age threshold due to these prolonged delays, jeopardizing their eligibility.
It's disheartening that while global competition for talented entrepreneurs and investors intensifies, Australia's business visa processing has almost ceased since 2022 under the current government.

We therefore ask the House to he Minister for Immigration and Citizenship to promptly address prolonged Subclass 188 visa processing delays. Prioritizing long-awaiting applicants is crucial to provide relief to affected individuals and their families, reaffirming Australia's commitment to entrepreneurship, investments, and economic growth. We urgently implore the Minister to address this situation, as it not only affects applicants but also damages Australia's reputation as an attractive destination for business and investment. As concerned citizens and stakeholders, we earnestly implore swift and equitable resolution of this issue.
from 1,466 citizens (Petition No. EN5837)
International Development Assistance
The Australian Government currently funds the UNRWA, a United Nations organisation for Palestinians, with $20 million every year.
There is substantial evidence that UNRWA's Education indoctrinates Palestinian children with hateful propaganda, and incites them to support and commit acts of terror.
Moreover, other elements of UNRWA, such as the providing of necessary supplies for Palestinians, are proven to have been used to facilitate terror.
Despite seeming like a genuine charitable organisation, UNRWA abuses its role to support hate, antisemitism and terror.
I therefore cannot accept Australian taxpayer money going towards such an organisation.
As a democracy that upholds the values of tolerance and peace, Australia must stop funding UNRWA.
We therefore ask the House to stop funding UNRWA, to preserve the values this country has worked so hard to achieve.
from 1,409 citizens (Petition No. EN5838)
Pensions and Benefits

"In the current situation, individuals on parenting payments and those with disabilities face penalties for not attending face-to-face appointments, despite their willingness to engage. This approach is inherently unjust, punishing individuals for not agreeing with the type of appointment rather than recognising their commitment to fulfilling the actual requirement (engagement,agree to job plan ect) . For some people, attending face to face appointments is just not that simple, due to things like social anxiety ect.

We therefore ask the House to eliminate punitive measures by granting flexibility for phone appointments, easing the burden on parenting payment recipients and individuals with disabilities engaging with employment providers."People shouldn't be punished for the method in which these appointments take place. It's about engagement and willingness to comply. Forcing in-person meetings creates undue hardship, undermining the genuine efforts of individuals. Allowing phone appointments acknowledges their commitment and ensures fair treatment in the pursuit of employment and support.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5842)
Rail Industry
Flying is difficult and expensive and it's hard to Navigate the airport
We therefore ask the House to build a bullet train linking all Australian capital cities including Darwin
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN5843)
Supported Employment Services
Crime Throughout ADE Employment

We therefore ask the House to take into account the fact that ADE Employment as it stands currently is unfair and un-just in many ways. People that operate those ADE (Australian Disability Enterprise) venues frequently take employees money for their own personal benefit and so much crime is committed in those places that any person thinks they can get away with anything I will not mention those crimes but employees and staff carry out those crimes more often than any person could want. Worse Still The pay rate provided employees is so low that 100% of the employees superannuation is taken away by administration of whichever company it is paid to so employees should not be paying any administration rate!
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5845)
Syria
The people of Syria are not our enemies. Yet Australia has lacked the commitment to seek the truth about the war in Syria while Syrians have become impoverished.

In response to the 21/08/2013 alleged sarin gas attack in Ghouta, Syria, America and Britain threatened military strikes against the Syrian Arab Republic. However, credible reports indicate it was most likely a false flag operation committed by the Al-Qaeda-affiliated Jabhat al-Nusra group and assisted by foreign intelligence agencies.

On 7/04/2018, an alleged chemical weapons attack in Douma, Syria, did result in western military strikes. However, the testimony of whistleblowers from the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) points to that alleged attack being another false flag operation.

Today, the West's unilateral coercive sanctions on Syria are having a catastrophic impact on the lives of Syrians. A recent UN commissioned report states: maintaining these sanctions 'may amount to a crime against humanity, against all Syrian people'.
In this dire situation, America occupies, controls, and benefits from Syria's resource-rich northeast region.

We therefore ask the House to call on the Australian government to suspend sanctions on Syria and for the House to set up a Parliamentary Friends of Syria group which would be tasked to support an open, thorough investigation into the alleged chemical weapons attacks; to reassess the autonomous sanctions imposed on Syria; and to evaluate if sanctions are crimes against the human rights of Syrians.
from 189 citizens (Petition No. EN5846)
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Gaza

On 19 December 2023, Australians received an email stating that the government will no longer provide consular assistance to evacuate family members from Gaza—despite already granting visas—leaving them trapped.

Those that attained a Visitor (subclass 600) visa will not receive any further assistance because they do not meet the definition of 'immediate family'—meaning a spouse/defacto or underage child. This effectively nullifies their visa and condemns them to increasingly desperate conditions in Gaza. Restricting the definition of 'immediate family' leaves behind siblings, cousins, aunts, uncles and grandparents, and has caused great financial and emotional distress for families of Gazans.

Getting out of Palestine without Australian Governmental assistance is not possible for most, due to the ongoing threat of the Israeli military. The people of Gaza deserve safe evacuation and arrival into Australia. Our government has the responsibility to expand visa access, including making Gazans eligible for humanitarian and other visa streams, and uphold the same consular assistance and support it has provided in the past.
Without the assistance of the government to advocate for them in negotiations with those that control Gaza's borders, the ability of Palestinians with visas to evacuate are severely hindered.
The government must uphold their promise and support.

We therefore ask the House to immediately re-establish direct support to Palestinians evacuating from Gaza, resume negotiations with forces that control Gaza's borders in order to ensure a safe and urgent evacuation for visa holders, and to expand Gazan's access to visas (including humanitarian visas).
from 5,089 citizens (Petition No. EN5847)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

During the review process only 10 000 Australians participated in the NDIS Review which was a rushed process over 12 months. Only 1000 of those were people who identified as disabled were involved out of 600 000 accessing the scheme. We call for a more consultative and engaged process with people who identify with having a disability about the proposed removal of hiring Unregistered Independent Workers and Businesses. This process is harmful and removes Choice and Control from people. Choice and Control were one of the initial pillars of the NDIS when it was bipartisanly legislated in 2013.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that this important choice to be legislated as an option that remains a permanent choice. We hire many small businesses and individuals in the service industry and feel no need to disclose our disability who are not a Registered Provider. There is also an important choice for disabled people living independently and engaging with the community to hire Independent Support Workers for a number of reasons. It is more cost effective as we can negotiate rates which you cannot do with Registered Providers. There is more control with training and how the person chooses to be supported in their daily life.
from 3,716 citizens (Petition No. EN5849)

subdebateinfo.title: Health Care: Goods and Services Tax

p.span: Health Care: Goods and Services Tax

The removal of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) on exercise physiology services is a significant step towards promoting public health and well-being in Australia. Exercise physiology plays a crucial role in preventing and managing various health conditions, including cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, and obesity. Moreover, exercise physiologists support a significant portion of our aging population to remain in their homes for as long as possible by helping maintain mobility and independence and reducing falls.
By eliminating the GST on these services, governments can encourage more individuals to seek professional guidance for their physical health and well-being.

This move is expected to make exercise physiology services more accessible and affordable for a broader segment of the population. The removal of GST recognises the importance of these services as an integral part of preventive healthcare, aligning with global efforts to prioritise health and wellness.
We therefore ask the House to remove GST from exercise physiology services
from 550 citizens (Petition No. EN5850)
Family Law

Currently the FCFCA is accepting laboratory reports for hair follicle drug testing from laboratories with a 'pay to win' ISO accreditation. These laboratories are in the US, UK and India. These labs do not meet Australian Standards and have never been inspected by an Australian regulator or industry body.

These results impact families adversely, they may split families up as a court will give significant weight to the laboratory report when deciding on child custody matters. If we are going to keep this process in the FCFCA (Federal Circuit and Family Court of Australia), we must ensure the testing has been done by an actual scientist in an actual laboratory.

We therefore ask the House to introduce an amendment to existing legislation or an order to the FCA (whichever is more practicable) to require a Registrar, Senior Judicial Registrar and/or Judges of the FCFCA to only order hair follicle testing through NATA (National Association of Testing Authorities) accredited laboratories and deem all results from non-NATA accredited laboratories to be null-and-void.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5852)
Veterans: Personal Information and Privacy

The Department of Veterans Affairs (DVA) has, for approximately 20 years been providing the personal and sensitive information of Veteran clients to the University of South Australia, this in order the University can administer the Medicines Advice and Therapeutics Education Services (MATES) program on behalf of the Department…

Information relating to how a Veterans information will be used is included on a letter the Veteran receives with their treatment card, and the wording on this letter can easily be understood to mean the "sharing" of information is a condition of use of the card. ''ADJ'' and the Secretary Department of Veterans Affairs' confirmed, that at the least there are concerns and vagaries surrounding how DVA shares Veterans personal information and obtains their consent…
The accompanying letter does not refer to MATES, the University of South Australia, or how a Veteran can refuse or withdraw consent, or how their information will be shared…

Any systemic ethical irregularities and other consequences which were identified by ADJ are yet to be fully explored and understood, however the ethics question could largely, if not entirely be eliminated if DVA immediately implemented a transparent and informative stand alone "opt in" consent policy.

We therefore ask the House to to initiate such processes, as to cause the DVA to implement a standalone opt in policy in instances where the Department identifies a need to share a Veterans personal information to any, and all third parties, including the University of South Australia.
from 125 citizens (Petition No. EN5853)
Veterans: Personal Information and Privacy

At 73 in ''ADJ'' and the Secretary Department of Veterans Affairs', the Australian Information Commissioner and Privacy Commissioner Ms Angeline Falk states, "Therefore, it is my view that while the complainant consented to the collection of the prescription information by the Department on the collection dates for the purpose of assessing and managing the complainant's MPBS claims, the complainant did not consent to the collection of information for the purposes of the Medicines Advice and Therapeutics Education Services (MATES) program"...
In this regard the circumstances of ADJ many if not every Veteran that has been provided a DVA treatment card, and this systemic failing is unacceptable.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes, as to cause the Secretary DVA to cease the practice of providing personal information to the MATES program unless the Veterans consent has first been obtained.
from 183 citizens (Petition No. EN5854)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following seven ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance: Overseas Visitor Health Cover

p.span: Private Health Insurance: Overseas Visitor Health Cover
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022, enclosing Petition EN4202, with two signatures, concerning Overseas Health Cover (OVHC). I apologise for the delay in responding.

In the majority of cases, visitors to Australia do not have access to Medicare and are responsible for costs associated with hospital, medical and para-medical health care rendered in Australia, whether provided in a public and/or private hospital.

OVHC is the result of arrangements between the Australian Government and certain registered health insurers for the provision of in-hospital medical treatment, public and private hospital accommodation costs, some out of hospital services (including General Practitioner consults), ambulance cover, and limited pharmaceuticals for visa holders.
The Australian Government website: www.privatehealth.gov.au provides information to help visitors to Australia choose a suitable insurance product.

Health insurers registered in Australia under the Private Health Insurance Act 2007 are eligible to provide OVHC if they have been approved to do so by the Department of Home affairs through a Deed of Agreement.
Currently, there are eight (8) Australian private health insurance business based in Australia approved to provide OVHC:
Allianz Care Australia
Australian Unity
BUPA
HBF Health
HCF (The Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia)
HIF (Health Insurance Fund of Australia)
Medibank Private
NIB

The availability of OVHC, cost for health insurance products and variation in the level of OVHC is acknowledged. Consumers are advised to take note of what is and is not covered under these products to ensure a comprehensive level of cover to meet individual health care needs. Visitors to Australia are strongly advised to compare health insurance providers to get the best value private health insurance product.
The requirement for a visa holder to "maintain adequate health insurance", is a requirement under condition 8501 of the Migration Regulations 1994.

The Department encourages all visitors to Australia to make arrangements for OVHC, regardless of whether or not it is a condition of their visa. This is to ensure all visa holders are fully covered for any unplanned medical or hospital care they may need while in Australia.
There are a range of options available for visa holders to acquire and maintain adequate health insurance cover for the duration of their stay in Australia.

Where condition 8501 is applied to a visa, there is no legislative requirement that the visa applicant (other than student visa applicants and holders) obtain an insurance product from an Australian insurer. Health Insurance provided by an overseas insurer may be acceptable.
For further information, refer to the Department's website: immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our-requirements/health/adequate-health-insurance
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4202 to my attention. Please accept my apologies for the delay in responding, I understand that there was a technical error with the transmission of your email.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Consumer Rights: Ticketed Events
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4350 on the ticket reselling company Viagogo. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Consumer Law (ACL) prohibits businesses, including ticket sellers and ticket resellers, ·from making false or misleading claims in their dealings with consumers. For example, businesses are not able to make false or misleading claims about an event or availability of tickets, or that the business is an authorised seller of tickets for an event if that is not the case.

Enhanced disclosure requirements for ticket resellers, including Viagogo, were recently introduced by the Competition and Consumer (Australian Consumer Law—Electronic Ticket Resale Service) Information Standard 2022. Ticket reseller websites must clearly display the following information:
a statement that says "This is a ticket resale service. You are not buying from a primary ticket provider", and
the total price that a consumer would reasonably be expected to pay if they purchased the ticket from an authorised ticket seller (alongside the resale price).

The ACL applies nationally and is administered jointly by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) and state and territory consumer protection agencies. In addition to these national protections, every state and territory except the Northern Territory and Tasmania have passed specific ticket reselling legislation. State-based legislation generally prohibits the resale of tickets at a price that exceeds 110 percent of the original ticket price.

If a constituent believes Viagogo's conduct has contravened the ACL or state/territory ticket reselling laws, I encourage them to report the issue to the ACCC or their state/territory consumer protection agency. The ACCC has previously taken action against Viagogo for breaching the Australian Consumer Law and in 2020 Viagogo was ordered to pay a penalty of $7 million for making false or misleading representations when reselling tickets for live music and sporting events.

In addition, the National Anti-Scam Centre, launched 1 July 2023, is an initiative to make Australia a harder target for scammers. The Centre will coordinate efforts to prevent scams by improving intelligence sharing across Government and the private sector and raising public awareness about scams. One of the Centre's priorities includes making it easier for consumers to report scams by connecting various reporting systems, so that consumers do not have to report a scam to several agencies. For more information, please visit: www.accc.gov.au/national-anti-scam-centre.

Finally, the Government's National Cultural Policy, Revive, released in January 2023, committed to take action to protect performers and audiences from ticket scalpers by working closely with the live performance industry, including on compliance with the Electronic Ticket Resale Service Information Standard.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Australian Competition and Consumer Commission
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5423 on including the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) in the 'Inquiry into ASIC's capacity and capability to respond to reports of alleged misconduct'. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
